children.text: In an auditory medium like radio, voice became essential for communicating necessary information, whether that simply meant distinguishing between different characters or communicating something
the characters themselves. In other words, as Shawn VanCour suggests in his study of 1920s radio drama, "in radio drama, it was the

actors' voices sounded that communicated their characters" (111). This need to "clearly differentiate and swiftly communicate characters" (VanCour 111) resulted in the development of stock voices that many radio dramas relied on. Stock voices became an easy way for radio dramas to imply a character's gender, race, class, ethnicity, geographical location, and more. Beyond these markers, VanCour notes that stock voices were also used to imply particular character tropes: "To this end, Rosaline Greene explained that the WGY's actors relied heavily on stock voices, favoring a 'light and lilting' voice for blondes, contralto voices for a 'dark-haired sexy person,' 'a thin quavery voice and a slower tempo' for elderly characters, and 'an oily smooth or steely rough voice' for a villain" (112).

Even when stock voices were not specifically relied upon, radio dramas had to make it clear to their audience when different characters were speaking. Ultimately, then, most voices on the radio had to be overly performed, with clearly enunciated speech, and sometimes even hokey. . In this particular excerpt, Hamlet is putting on a play intended to expose his uncle's guilt. Pay special attention to the tenor, tone, and depth of each voice, as they help a listening audience distinguish between the various characters in this scene.
